headline: CNN This Morning
subHeadline: Harley Finkelstein is Interviewed about Black Friday Sales; Russell Levinson Jr. is Interviewed about the Bushs; Vikings Rally Patriots. Aired 6:30-7a ET

utterances.speaker: DON LEMON, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: We have that dilemma.

utterances.speaker: KAITLAN COLLINS, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: I would totally go to Taco Bell.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Our -

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Why?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: We had to do appetizers. And so we had like -- it was beef and pork meatballs and whatever and like, oh, wait a minute, there's a lot of vegetarians.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Why, someone's a vegetarian.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes, grab a vegetable.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: This is not your holiday. Not your holiday.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: So, we saw Alison Kosik out. She's at the famous Macy's in Harold Square, Remember "Miracle on 34th Street," that Macy's. It's still early but millions have already had a jumpstart on Black Friday shopping or, as Chad Myers calls it, slick Friday.Are we tracking - and we're tracking purchases, yes, we are, all across the country in real time. This is with the data and the trends. And Spotify President Harley Finkelstein will show us. We're going to go to him now. Good morning, sir. How are you?

utterances.speaker: HARLEY FINKELSTEIN, PRESIDENT, SHOPIFY
utterances.sentences: Good morning. It's Shopify, by the way. Spotify's another great company. But Shopify.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Oh, so what did I say?

utterances.speaker: FINKELSTEIN
utterances.sentences: You said Spotify. It's a great company.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I said Shopify?

utterances.speaker: FINKELSTEIN
utterances.sentences: I love them too, but Shopify is totally different.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I got shopping on the brain. So -

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: You can listen to music while you shop.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thank you. It's - it's - it is -

utterances.speaker: FINKELSTEIN
utterances.sentences: Actually, that's like a partnership made in heaven.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: All right, so, I'm a little froggy - foggy this morning.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Also froggy.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I can barely talk.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: It's OK.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Happy belated Thanksgiving. So glad you could join us.So, what are - what are the trends showing? What are we seeing?

utterances.speaker: FINKELSTEIN
utterances.sentences: So, let's kind of start at the top here.This Black Friday, Cyber Monday, first and foremost, it seems less frantic. There is less supply chain issues. There are more physical stores that are open. And there's been better capacity planning. And so we're seeing a lot more stability, I think, than before. If you go back to last year, Shopify saw, during the four days, like Black Friday/Cyber Monday, but 47 million shoppers shop across our stores. They sold - they sold about $6.3 billion of sale. And we saw a peak of $3.1 million happen on -- per minute on Black Friday. That was the peak. So, so far what we're seeing today, again, it's still very early, Black Friday has really just begun. But yesterday peak sales were about 1.52 million per minute at around 6:04 p.m. last year. That's up from about 1.49 at the peak last year for Thanksgiving. We're also seeing that the average cart price is up relative to last year. We're seeing our average cart price around $109, compared to $105 last year. If you think about what product categories are doing really well, there are five that are - that seem to be really hitting out of the park. The first is apparel and accessories. The second is health and beauty. Third is home and garden. Fourth is food and beverage. And fifth is electronics. So, you're - you are seeing healthy shopping across a lot of different verticals. And Shopify is --

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Wait, wait, what are those again? You said the first one's what?

utterances.speaker: FINKELSTEIN
utterances.sentences: So, apparel and accessories.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Apparel. OK.

utterances.speaker: FINKELSTEIN
utterances.sentences: Health and beauty.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: FINKELSTEIN
utterances.sentences: Home and garden. Food and beverage. And electronics.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Why is electronics - that's low. I thought it would be higher.

utterances.speaker: FINKELSTEIN
utterances.sentences: Well, it's not necessarily low, it's just low relative to some of the others. In fact, if you look at our top trend products right now, three out of the four are actually cosmetics. Pat McGrath Labs, MERIT Beauty and Beachwaver curling iron. The fourth is Our Place, which is the always plan, which is this amazing cooking pans. So, you are seeing a lot of cosmetics get a lot of attention right now.The other thing, Don, that is important to see here is that physical retail is absolutely back.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: FINKELSTEIN
utterances.sentences: Point of sale, like physical retail sales, made by Shopify merchants in the U.S. have grown 26 percent since Thanksgiving last year. So, definitely consumers are going into those stores.And in terms of, you know, what we're seeing at Shopify, if you go right now, anyone can see this, if you go to datastories.shopify.com, you will see a real live map of exactly what is happening across global commerce. Shopify has millions of stores. We have about 10 percent of all ecommerce in the U.S. goes through Shopify. And right now we're seeing almost 3 million unique shoppers - you know, it's 6:00, 6:30 in the morning EST, but 3 million unique shoppers shopping across Shopify stores. Sales per minute are above 850,000 per minute.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: But, Harley -

utterances.speaker: FINKELSTEIN
utterances.sentences: So, there's a lot of attention right now. A lot of action.

utterances.speaker: FINKELSTEIN
utterances.sentences: You know, I -- I actually -- I heard this on your show on Wednesday. You folks were talking about the Consumer Sentiment Index. So, the Consumer Sentiment Index, which was expected to be 54.9 points, on Wednesday it was reported at 56.8 points. So, the Consumer Sentiment Index is even higher than what people saw it - what people thought it would be. And we've already seen really positive predictions for this holiday season.So, you know, a couple things, it's way to early to say exactly what's going to happen here. But we already - we were already seeing numbers slightly up from last year based on Thanksgiving peek sales per minute. And I think that, you know, one of the - one of the other major, you know, takeaways from this, this season is, this Black Friday/Cyber Monday period is no longer just a weekend. It's really become a season.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: That's what you were saying.

utterances.speaker: FINKELSTEIN
utterances.sentences: And I think that a lot of consumers were shopping earlier and looking for discounts.But the major trend here is intentionality. We really are seeing that consumers are buying in a very intentional way. They want to buy from their favorite brands. They do want to find discounts, but they want to support their favorite brands and they want to buy direct as much as possible.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: So, Kaitlan and I - Kaitlan was just saying that she was -- about Black Friday, that you thought it was not just a day.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: It's changed so much. We -- my family, when I was younger, we used to get up early. We'd go physically to the stores to wait in line.

utterances.speaker: FINKELSTEIN
utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE). You'd line up, I think, right? You'd get - you'd line up outside. Sure.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Exactly. You'd line up.

utterances.speaker: FINKELSTEIN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: And you just don't seem to see that anymore because as you were - as you were talking about -

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: All those people like killing themselves for televisions and remember like (INAUDIBLE)?

utterances.speaker: FINKELSTEIN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes. It was crazy. FINKELSTEINyou know, the doors open, everyone kind of tramples on each other. That, I mean, you may see some of that today. I don't know if that's going to be the case or not. You're just seeing less of it. And part of it is that I think we've extended this Black Friday/Cyber Monday weekend into more of a season. And I think when you layer on top of that this - this - this real propensity for consumers to like - you know, what I'm buying right now are my favorite brands. I'm buying Vuori. I'm buying Alo Yoga. I'm buying James Perse. I'm buying Bleusalt. I want to support the brands that I love the most. And, lucky for me, those are all Shopify brands. But I think there is more intentionality now around buying great value and actually, you know, supporting brands and voting with your wallets for those brands to exist.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I think it's amazing, if we look at - and we have it on the wall over here. Like, that's why I keep looking - I'm not ignoring Kaitlan, we were looking at the wall over here, looking at all of the - I mean this is pretty amazing how you guys track this stuff. So, you can do the United States. You can do worldwide. You can do other countries.What about worldwide? I mean this -- we're an international show. Is this, what's happening in the United States, is that reflected worldwide?

utterances.speaker: FINKELSTEIN
utterances.sentences: Yes, so we're an international company. Shopify has millions of stores in more than 175 countries. We really are the dominant commerce player, not just for people getting started, but also for very large brands, whether it's Spanx or it's Mattel or it's companies like Allbirds or FIGS or Bombas or Gymshark. So, we have merchants in 175 countries. And this is reflective around the world.Now, Black Friday really started as a U.S. Thing. It really was something that started in the U.S. but it really has -- has migrated all over the world. I'm in Canada today. It's a big day in Canada as well. So, again, it's everywhere and it's not just four days, but this is certainly going to be the day to watch. If you're interested in really geeky, nerdy retail and commerce data, check out datastories.shopify.com. You'll see everything. And it's happening in hyper real time. It's really cool.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: I -

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes. We just want to know where the sales are.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes, just send them to Don and I directly.

utterances.speaker: FINKELSTEIN
utterances.sentences: Good plan (ph).

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: All right, Harley, thank you so much for breaking all that down.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thanks, Harley.

utterances.speaker: FINKELSTEIN
utterances.sentences: Thank you. Thanks so much.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Have a great holiday season. We'll see you soon. Thanks.

utterances.speaker: FINKELSTEIN
utterances.sentences: You as well. Happy holidays.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: All right, also this morning, this is Twitter. Every day there's a headline about what's happening.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I know.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: This time Elon Musk is saying he's going to restore banned Twitter accounts, a move that one unexpert says is like opening the gates of hell.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: It's beginning to look like - we looks so weird. Look at us.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: I can't stop - I mean, speaking of Black Friday, maybe we should buy some new clothes so we don't look like identical twins.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: We - we did not plan this.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: I know. Great minds dress alike.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: The holiday season is here,, which means the classic movies and TV specials are back. This year, CNN is bringing you a unique look at all your favorites.A quick preview for you. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TOM HANKS, ACTOR
utterances.sentences: Christmas movies and television specials are always about someone who has lost their faith in humankind regaining it.PHIL ROSENTHAL, CREATOR, "EVERYBODY LOVES RAYMOND": "A Christmas Story" is one of the best movies about nostalgia, family and Christmas.

utterances.speaker: SARA SIDNER, JOURNALIST, CNN
utterances.sentences: I watch it every year at least twice. It's the script of my life.

utterances.speaker: RAMI MALEK, ACTOR
utterances.sentences: It's hard to beat "Home Alone." Just fun and hijinks.DAVID E. TALBERT, WRITER/DIRECTOR: It is on the Mount Rushmore of holiday movies.

utterances.speaker: RON HOWARD, DIRECTOR
utterances.sentences: I lost myself in "Miracle on 34th Street."ALONSO DURALDE, FILM CRITIC/AUTHOR: "National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation" was capturing how the holidays make us all insane. BEN MANKIEWICZ, HOST, "TURNER CLASSIC MOVIES": There is that consistent Christmas element in "Elf" of change, of realization.

utterances.speaker: TIM NAFTALI, CNN CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.sentences: Watch a good Christmas show and it doesn't matter when it was made. These ideas don't get old.

utterances.speaker: ANNOUNCER
utterances.sentences: Unwrap the stories behind everything we love to watch at Christmas. A two-hour special event "Tis the Season(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: "Tis the Season

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: I feel like the minute Thanksgiving dinner is over and you're packing up the leftovers, it's Christmas season, and it's time to watch movies.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I think it's before. But she - she is -- we put up our Christmas tree -

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: I know. I think you're crazy.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: She's like, too soon.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: It's too soon.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: She's already up (ph).

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: It is a hard and fast rule it's the day after Thanksgiving.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I put up our Christmas tree on Tuesday.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: That's not too bad. I guess that's not too bad.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: What's your favorite Christmas movie?

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: I was just watching that, and I agree with Alonso about "National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation." We always watch it. And, you know, the couple in it that's like - they're like neighbors next door that are kind of like pretentious and above all the craziness and they're like fancy.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: My family always makes fun of me and says that's me where they're like, why is the carpet all wet, Todd?

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: I'm telling, if my family's watching this, they always say that I'm Margo. And I'm like, that is so unfair.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I am a little bit more traditional.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: I know. I picked a funny one and you're like a classy -

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: "It's a Wonderful Life." I always cry. And I feel like I live in a -- I mean, I love it. It is the best movie. I cry every year. And I know what's going to happen. And then, what's the other one? "Miracle on 34th Street."

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: That's a good one.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: The one with Natalie Wood.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: That's a good one. The Charlie Brown one.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I love it. The courtroom scene. Have you -- do you - do you know this movie?

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: So, when they bring - they're like, Santa Claus doesn't exist. And they said -- I'm not giving it away. But if it's recognized by the U.S. --

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: It's been out for like decades.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Well, I mean, some kids may be watching.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Spoiler alert.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: If the U.S. government recognizes that Santa Claus is real -

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Then Santa Claus is real and that he is the Santa Claus. And then they bring in all of this mail that people have sent to Santa Claus to the U.S. Post Office and said, that's it, he is Santa Claus, Kris Kringle. And then the other one is "Scrooge," I think it's "A Christmas Carol." Is that right?

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: "A Christmas Carol."

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: The one with Alastair Sim, the black and white one.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Not any of the other ones. The other ones are not real. That's my favorite.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: It's funny how people just rewatch Christmas movies. Like, they never get old.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Over and over.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Even though you know - you can like quote them.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: I'm going to watch the new - we're - I'm going home today. We're going to watch the Will Ferrell/Ryan Reynolds new one that just came out.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes, yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: It's going to be fun, I think.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: We want - we're trying to get Will to come on. We're working on that. That could happen.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Well, we'll see. It looks like a good movie.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Do you - what's the other one? Do you like -- like animated - I mean you're a bit older than me, the animated ones like "Rudolph"? Did you used to do that?

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes, I - those -- we always watched those growing up.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: OK, good.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: You know, Charlie Brown Christmas tree, all those were just classics.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes. Those are good.All right, well, back to work. We forgot -- I forgot we were on television for a minute.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: I know.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: The Lakers Patrick Beverly suspended for a shoving incident in part because of his history of unsportsmanlike conduct on the court.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: You might remember that moving eulogy from Reverend Russell Levinson Jr. for former President George H.W. Bush. That was at his state funeral in D.C. in 2018. Now the reverend is reflecting on the firsthand experience that he had, spending so much time, intimate time, with the former president and his wife, Barbara, and their relationship with faith. It's in his new book, "Witness to DignityAnd the Reverend Russell Levenson Jr. of St. Martin's Episcopal Church is joining us now. So, we're so grateful you're getting up with us from Birmingham, Alabama, where I'm --.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Good morning. Can I just say, before Kaitlan starts, it's a -- we have the book. It's such a beautiful book.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: It's amazing.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: And the photo on the cover, I mean, it's just fantastic. And I cannot -- I haven't had a chance to read it. I cannot wait to read it.But, happy belated Thanksgiving. Thanks for joining us today.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: You're going to love it.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: It's really so interesting.And I loved what you said, that you kind of felt like given, Reverend, that you had this first-hand experience with them, that you kind of felt like you had a responsibility to share the wisdom that you - that you learned from them and that you saw them talk about so much. REV. RUSSELL LEVENSON JR., RECTOR, ST. MARTIN'S EPISCOPAL CHURCH: Yes, I mean, when the -- it's good to be on with you. I will say, I did catch the end of the last segment and you forgot "The Bishop's Wife." I would add that to the list of great Christmas movies.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Oh, that -- that's really good. You're right about that. We missed it.

utterances.speaker: LEVENSON
utterances.sentences: Since we're hitting theological notes this morning.Yes, you know, my wife, Laura (ph), and I said that we were fortunate to kind of live in the university of George H.W. Bush and Barbara Bush for eleven and a half years. And - and that's what the book is about. It really is about our experience of knowing them and getting to know them and getting to watch them, which inspired the title, really. It's my witness box moment for eleven and a half years of watching the way in which they lived their lives, the way in which they lived with others and treated others. And - and really, I think, really born of their true and earnest faith which carried them all the way to the end, which is I -- as you just pointed out, Kaitlan, that I was there for both of them as they died and was able to plan their funerals with them. But they were just wonderful, dignified, decent, godly people. Not perfect. You know, quick to say, nobody is. That's my boss' job. But everybody that was around them, particularly those last several years, got to watch really them grow in their faith such that when it came to the end they were at peace and really in charity with everybody around them.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes. You know, it's interesting, you know, because presidents have to deal so much - you know, deal with so much when they're in office, right, with world affairs, right, and so they have to make really tough decisions. But I think, and you can tell me if I'm wrong or not, you can judge someone, a president, or a former president and first lady, by their time after they are in office, what they choose to do with their time. The people they choose to spend their time with. The causes they choose to take up.And when you talk about the dignity, I mean, look, you -- the testimonials that's in your book are from people from all walks of life, all different political stripes, all different backgrounds, all different ethnicities, said a lot about the Bushs.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: And what about the lessons that political leaders now could have? Because, you know, anyone can look at the climate in the United States and see that it's incredibly troubled. And I think you said that, you know, part of the book is talking about having godly, dignified leaders of character is not only possible but it's necessary.

utterances.speaker: LEVENSON
utterances.sentences: Yes, I think so. I -- you know, I think it's important to note, and I say this again in the book, I don't -- you know, we -- we're not -- we never elect a theologian-in-chief. So I'm - I don't think the president, from what I know and what I watched, or Barbara, used their faith to further their political aims or goals. I think they were shaped by their faith, grew up in the faith, they were shaped by their relationship with their Lord and - and their faithfulness in such a way that that played out in their -- in his policy making and the way in which they took on very important service initiatives throughout the country.And, you know, I think if you look at the chief ethic of the Judeo Christian faith, which is what they were adherence to, they were faithful Episcopalians and that chief ethic is love and charity and kindness and the way in which we should deal with others. I don't think they saw political opponents. I don't think they ever saw them as enemies. I think they saw them as opponents. But I think often they found a way to work together with those folks. And I think that sprung out of their faith. So, I think when we do choose people to lead us, we want people who don't use their faith to further their aims, but they are informed and shaped by their faith to make a difference in the world. And look at what he did in those four years he had in office.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEVENSON
utterances.sentences: And look at what they did in the 11 years or so that I knew them on so many service initiatives that I saw, again, up until the end of their lives.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes. It's a lovely message.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thank you.The book is called "Witness to Dignity: The Life and Faith of George H.W. and Barbara Bush." It's a beautiful, beautiful book.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes.Reverend, thank you so much for coming on with us.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: LEVENSON
utterances.sentences: God bless.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Be well.So, listen, we were talking about -- it was a thrilling football - a thrilling Thanksgiving Day for football fans, including Poppy Harlow, who was at the Vikings game last night. Andy Scholes has all the latest on the game day highlights. Andy, hello to you. Poppy's happy this morning.

utterances.speaker: ANDY SCHOLES, CNN SPORTS CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Oh, I'm sure she is. I saw her Instagram. She was having the time of her life last night, as were all the Vikings fans. You know, they were - they were certainly pumped up because it was their first ever Thanksgiving Day game that they got to host. They were taking on the Patriots.Now, in the third quarter we had a little bit of controversy. New England thought they had a touchdown right here, Mac Jones to Hunter Henry. Certainly looks like a great catch. They called it a touchdown. But upon review, they said it was incomplete. The ball hit the ground. Patriots couldn't believe it. Henry saying afterwards he thought he had his hands under it the whole time. Pats had to settle for a field goal there. They took a three-point lead. With the game tied in the fourth quarter, Kirk Cousins to Adam Thielen for the score there. That was his third TD pass of the game. Vikings take the lead for good. They would win, 33-26. The Bills, meanwhile, playing in Detroit for the second time in five days. And before the game, check this out. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Oh my God!(END VIDEO CLIP)
